Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations. Athlete’s foot is a fungal infection that typically occurs with people whose feet become sweaty while wearing tight fitting shoes. An athletic trainer plans to conduct a study to investigate the following claim made in a sports medicine journal. For people who suffer from athlete’s foot, Foot Ointment C is less effective than Foot Ointment D in curing the infection. The trainer will randomly assign <math alttext="180" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>180</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> volunteers with athlete’s foot to use one of two foot ointments, with <math alttext="90" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>90</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> assigned to use Foot Ointment C each day and the remaining <math alttext="90" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>90</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> assigned to use Foot Ointment D each day. The trainer will record the number of people cured after one month for each foot ointment. (a) Describe the benefit of randomly assigning the type of foot ointment to the volunteers.

(b) Describe a process that can be used to randomly assign the <math alttext="180" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>180</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people to the two foot ointments.

The results are shown in the following segmented bar graphs. (c) For the <math alttext="180" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>180</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> volunteers in the study, is there support for the journal’s claim? Justify your answer using values from the segmented bar graph. Do not perform an inferential procedure.

The trainer conducted a hypothesis test to investigate the journal’s claim. Let <math alttext="p sub C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> be the proportion of people similar to those in the study with athlete’s foot who would be cured using Foot Ointment C and <math alttext="p sub D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>D</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> be the proportion of people similar to those in the study with athlete’s foot who would be cured using Foot Ointment D. The hypotheses of the test are: <math alttext="H sub 0: p sub C equals p sub D. H sub a: p sub C is less than p sub D." overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>{</mo><mtable columnalign="left" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>D</mtext></mrow></msub></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>a</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>D</mtext></mrow></msub></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> (d) Explain why it is reasonable to conclude that the sampling distribution of <math alttext="p hat sub C minus p hat sub D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover></mrow><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>−</mo><msub><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover></mrow><mrow><mtext>D</mtext><mtext></mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is approximately normal.

(e) Based on the hypothesis test and resulting <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value of <math alttext="0.034" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.034</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, what can the trainer conclude about the journal’s claim? Explain your answer.
